questions.question:
Question 1: A hypertensive patient was brought to the emergency due to complaints of palpitations and 
breathing difficulty. Comment on his ECG.
questions.explanation:
The above ECG shows a pattern of premature ventricular contractions, one premature beat after 
one normal beat. This is seen in ventricular bigeminy. Premature ventricular contractions/beats (PVC) are single ventricular beats that occur earlier than 
the next normal supraventricular beat. They originate from abnormal foci in the ventricular 
tissue: • Unifocal PVCs arise from a single focus and hence have the same QRS morphology 871 
Sold by @itachibot • Multifocal PVCs arise from multiple foci and therefore have different QRS morphologies They are not preceded by a P wave as they do not originate in the atria. They show wide QRS 
complexes (>0.12 ms) on the ECG because they are conducted via normal myocardial tissue 
instead of the Purkinje system. Ventricular bigeminy refers to a pair of normal and premature ventricular contractions, whereas 
ventricular trigeminy refers to a premature beat that occurs after two normal beats. Quadrigeminy 
is when a premature beat follows three normal beats. Few other terms associated with premature ventricular contractions: • Two successive PVCs are known as a couplet • Three successive PVCs are known as a triplet. The given ECG shows ventricular bigeminy with premature beats circled in red and normal 
ventricular contractions circled in green.

questions.question:
Question 2: Identify the marked ECG feature in a patient diagnosed with ventricular tachycardia. 860 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The ECG feature of ventricular tachycardia seen in the given image is a fusion beat. It occurs when 
a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex. Ventricular tachycardia (VT) is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions at a 
rate of >100/min. It is characterized by: • Wide QRS complex • AV dissociation- Atrial activity independent of ventricular activity, seen on the ECG as every p 
wave not followed by QRS complex • Fusion beats- occur when a sinus and ventricular beat coincide to produce a hybrid complex • Capture beats occur when the SA node transiently ‘captures’ the ventricles, that is, ventricles are 
depolarized by the impulses from the SA node producing a QRS complex of normal duration. 872 
Sold by @itachibot The given ECG shows a fusion beat (red arrow), and a capture beat (green arrow) can also be seen: The given image shows capture beats in VT: Option C: Polymorphic QRS, that is, continuously changing QRS morphology is seen in 
polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. Option D: Triphasic QRS (eg. RSR pattern on V1) is seen in supraventricular tachycardias with 
the wide QRS complex.

questions.question: Question 3: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below?
questions.explanation:
The rate of the given ECG is around 188 BPM ( >100 BPM) and it shows wide QRS complexes ( 
 0.12 s) with abnormal morphology (red arrows) and absence of P waves which suggests a 
diagnosis of ventricular tachycardia. 873 
Sold by @itachibot Ventricular fibrillation (Option B) would not show discreet QRS complexes, and hence is not the 
answer in this case.

questions.question:
Question 4: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency following an episode of syncope during his 
morning walk. His blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. He has a history of myocardial infarction 
5 yrs back. His present ECG is given below. Which is the most appropriate treatment for the 
patient?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario describes a man with history of coronary artery disease developing 
syncope. The ECG shows wide QRS complex (> 0.12 s) tachycardia with a single QRS 
morphology suggestive of monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT). The most appropriate 
treatment of VT in a hemodynamically unstable (systolic blood pressure < 90 mm Hg) patient 
is DC cardioversion. VT can be casued by structural heart disease, scar-related reentry, cardiomyopathies, or 
abnormalities in the conduction pathways. VT is said to be sustained if it lasts for at least 30 
seconds or requires intervention for termination. 874 
Sold by @itachibot Rapid VT can lead to hypotension and syncope, especially in patients with ventricular 
dysfunction. Patients with normal cardiac function may tolerate sustained VT, presenting with 
palpitations. Monomorphic VT associated with structural heart disease can progress to ventricular 
fibrillation (VF) and sudden cardiac arrest. QRS synchronous electrical cardioversion is performed for unstable patients. Intravenous 
amiodarone is the preferred drug for stable VT associated with heart disease. After restoring sinus rhythm, further evaluation is necessary to determine the underlying heart 
disease. Treatment options include antiarrhythmic medications, catheter ablation, or implantable 
cardioverter-defibrillators (ICDs) for recurrent or high-risk VT. ICDs are commonly used for 
secondary prevention of sudden death in patients with sustained VT and structural heart disease.

questions.question:
Question 5: All of the following are effective in the management of patients with ventricular tachycardia 
except:
questions.explanation:
Carotid sinus massage will be effective only in supraventricular tachycardias but not in ventricular 
tachycardias. This is because it acts by increasing the AV node block which does not play any role 
in the pathogenesis of ventricular tachycardia. Hence, AV node blocking maneuvers (carotid sinus massage, valsalva) and drugs (adenosine) are 
not used in the management of VT.

questions.question: Question 6: Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is the most common arrhythmia associated with:
questions.explanation:
Accelerated idioventricular rhythm is the most common arrhythmia associated with myocardial 
reperfusion, most commonly in the first 2 days after presentation. Idioventricular rhythm is defined as  3 consecutive premature ventricular contractions with a 
heart rate of <50 bpm. If the heart rate is 60-100 bpm, it is known as accelerated idioventricular 
rhythm, and if it is more than 100 bpm it is known as ventricular tachycardia. It may be the result 
of an abnormal focus in the ventricle that generates an impulse faster than the sinus node and 
therefore assumes control. Other causes of AIVR include: • Buerger disease • Congenital heart disease • Dilated cardiomyopathy • Myocarditis • Drugs: Digoxin toxicity, cocaine toxicity, and various anesthesia agents • Electrolyte abnormality • Postresuscitation Episodes of AIVR have not been found to affect prognosis in acute MI and usually do not require 
intervention. If AIVR is accompanied by hemodynamic compromise, treatment with atropine or 
atrial pacing will often suppress the rhythm. 875 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for all of the 
following conditions except:

options.c: Acute coronary syndrome with low ejection fraction

questions.explanation:
An automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) is a device placed in the chest or 
abdomen to detect arrhythmias and perform cardioversion, defibrillation, and pace the heart. It is contraindicated in patients experiencing tachyarrhythmias with reversible or transient causes 
such as acute MI. It is used in: • Brugada syndrome- refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can 
lead to sudden cardiac death. • Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia. • Cardiac resynchronization therapy for prevention of sudden cardiac death in heart failure. • High-risk situations of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.question: Question 8: Sudden cardiac death is defined as unexpected nontraumatic death in stable patients within:
questions.explanation:
Sudden cardiac death is defined as unexpected non-traumatic death in clinically well or stable 
patients who die within 1 hour after onset of symptoms. The causative rhythm in most cases is ventricular fibrillation, which is usually preceded by 
ventricular tachycardia except in the setting of acute ischemia or infarction.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 60-year-old man with a history of ischemic heart disease is brought to the emergency in an 
unconscious state. He has been neglecting symptoms of dizziness and palpitations for the 
past few days. His ECG is given below. The most possible diagnosis is: 863 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG is suggestive of ventricular fibrillation. The features in the above ECG that support the diagnosis are: • Disordered electrical ventricular activation with no identifiable QRS complexes • No identifiable P-waves, no PR interval Possible mechanisms of ventricular fibrillation include spiral wave reentry and multiple 
circulating reentry wavefronts. The ECG features suggestive of ventricular tachycardia are as follows: • Wide QRS complex with abnormal morphology (marked with red arrows in image below) • Absence of the P waves • Rate >100/min- in the ECG below, it is ~180 beats/min (1500/no. of small boxes between two 
R waves) 876 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient who is a known case of Crohn's disease was brought to the emergency. He 
complained of sudden onset cold sweats and palpitations. Which among the following is the 
likely cause of his ECG finding shown in the given image?
questions.explanation:
The given ECG finding shows torsades de pointes, which can occur due to 
hypomagnesemia (Crohn's disease causes chronic diarrhea which can cause excess GI loss of 
magnesium). Torsades de pointes means twisting of points, it implies twisting of the QRS complexes around the 
isoelectric line of the ECG. It is a form of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia that is seen in 
patients with a prolonged QT interval. A prolonged QT interval usually results from prolonged ventricular repolarization (lengthening of 
T wave). A premature ventricular contraction falling in the elongated T wave can initiate torsades 
de pointes. The features of torsades de pointes are: • Polymorphic QRS complexes that change in amplitude • Cycle length giving an appearance of oscillations around the baseline • QT prolongation 877 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What 
is the best step in the management of the condition?
questions.explanation:
The given ECG showing a wide QRS complex tachycardia with waxing and waning QRS amplitude 
points to the diagnosis of torsades des pointes. As the patient is hemodynamically stable, 
intravenous MgSO4 is the treatment of choice. Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) has a continually changing QRS morphology. 
Polymorphic VT that occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired prolongation of QT interval 
is referred to as torsades des pointes. Patients present with near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac 
arrest. IV MgSO4 is highly effective for both treatment and the prevention of recurrence of long 
QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that trigger torsades des pointes. If magnesium alone is ineffective, isoproterenol infusion or pacing, to a rate of 100-120 
depolarization/minute usually suppresses VT recurrences. If the patient is hemodynamically unstable, then immediate defibrillation should be done. Synchronized cardioversion 
Defibrillation Used in ventricular tachycard 
iawithout a pulse, and ventric 
ular fibrillation. Used inunstable PSVT, atrial 
flutter, atrial fibrillation, and 
ventricular tachycardiawith a 
pulse Shock is delivered at any tim 
e during the cardiac cycle. Shock is delivered in sync wit 
h the R wave (in absolute refr 
actory period) Monophasic - 100 to 200› 
Monophasic - 360› Biphasic - 50 to 100› 
Biphasic - 120 to 200› 878 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Identify the false statement about the bundle of Kent.

options.a: It is faster than AV nodal pathway
options.b: It is slower than AV nodal pathway

questions.explanation:
The bundle of Kent is the accessory pathway of conduction between the atria and ventricle in 
Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. It conducts impulses faster than the AV nodal pathway 
and avoids AV nodal delay, leading to shortened PR interval. QRS is prolonged because of the AV 
nodal impulse reaching the ventricles after the aberrant impulse.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is seen in patients with Brugada syndrome?

options.c: ST segment elevation in 1, V5, AvL
options.d: ST segment elevation in II , III AvF

questions.explanation:
The major feature of Brugada syndrome is transient or concealed ST-segment elevation in V1 to 
V3. Brugada syndrome is a rare syndrome characterized by ST-segment elevation and negative T 
waves in more than 1 anterior precordial leads ( V1- V3 ). It is associated with mutations involving 
cardiac sodium channels. The patients have episodes of polymorphic VT which may lead to 
syncope or cardiac arrest. It shows an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern and affects males more than females. The 
episodes of VT may occur either in sleep or maybe provoked by febrile illness or sodium 
channel-blocking drugs (Class I antiarrhythmics) like ajmaline, flecainide, and procainamide. The episodes of VT can be suppressed using quinidine or catheter ablation. ICD can be used in 
individuals who have been resuscitated from cardiac arrest.

questions.question: Question 14: Brugada syndrome is associated with:
questions.explanation:
Brugada syndrome is associated with right bundle branch block. It is an inherited disease that 
predisposes patients to potentially life threatening arrythmias. The ECG below is depictive of Brugada syndrome with concave ST segments and negative T waves 
(to be seen in more than one anterior precordial leads, i.e., V1-V3) 879 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Romano-Ward syndrome is:

options.a: Congenital short PR associated with deafness
options.c: Congenital long QT associated with cataract

questions.explanation:
Romano-Ward syndrome is a congenital long QT syndrome without deafness. Romano-Ward syndrome is associated with specific genetic mutations affecting membrane 
potassium and sodium channels. The inheritance pattern may be autosomal recessive or 
autosomal dominant. The preferred drugs for managing this condition are the beta-blockers. Implantable 
cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) implantation can also be done. ›ervell-Lange-Nielsen syndrome is congenital long QT with deafness. LOF= Loss of Function GOF= Gain of Function DISORD

questions.question:
Question 16: The ECG of a patient as given below is suggestive of: 866 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above ECG rhythm strip shows 1st degree AV Block. The following features of this ECG support the diagnosis: • The P wave precedes each and every QRS complex • PR interval is prolonged • The PR interval is constant in every beat 881 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following conditions is associated with AV block?
questions.explanation:
Hypothyroidism is associated with AV block. In hypothyroidism, there is reduced myocardial 
contractility and reduced pulse rate leading to a reduced stroke volume and bradycardia, AV 
block. Causes of AV block: Autonomic: • Carotid sinus hypersensitivity Metabolic: • Hyperkalemia • Hypermagnesemia • Hypothyroidism • Adrenal insufficiency Drug related: • Beta blockers • Calcium channel blockers • Adenosine • Digitalis • Lithium • Class 1 and class 3 anti arrhythmics Infections: • Endocarditis 882 
Sold by @itachibot • Lyme disease • Chaga's disease • Syphilis • Tuberculosis • Diphtheria • Toxoplasmosis Inflammatory: • SLE • RA • Scleroderma Infiltrative: • Amyloidosis • Sarcoidosis • Hemachromatosis

questions.question:
Question 18: A concerned wife brought her 43-year-old husband to the clinic after an episode of 
light-headedness and palpitations. An ECG was taken. What is the diagnosis? 867 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
This patient has symptoms and ECG findings suggestive of Mobitz type I or Wenckebach block. In the given ECG PR segment progressively increases in each successive cycle, until a P wave of 
the series fails to produce a QRS complex (dropped QRS). In this example, for every 5 'P' waves, 
there are only 4 'QRS' complexes; hence, this is a 5:4 Wenckebach block.

questions.question: Question 19: All of the following may be seen in Mobitz type II heart block except:

options.b: Atrial rate more than the ventricular rate

questions.explanation:
The absence of a constant relationship between the P wave and the QRS complex (P-QRS 
dissociation) is a feature of complete heart block. It is not seen in Mobitz type II second-degree 
heart block. The PR interval remains constant in Mobitz type II second-degree heart block but few p waves are 
not followed by QRS complex. It occurs due to a block in the bundle of His. The atrial rate is more 
than the ventricular rate.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 56-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room after she lost consciousness briefly 
during a speech. An ECG was taken immediately. What is the most likely diagnosis? 868 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given ECG shows a constant PR interval in each successive cycle followed by a dropped 
QRS (P wave fails to produce a QRS complex). This pattern is suggestive of Mobitz type II block. 883 
Sold by @itachibot Mobitz type II block is characterized by an intermittent failure of conduction of the p 
wave without any change in the preceding impulses. The dropped QRS is marked in the image below: Note: Bradyarrhythmias that cause syncope include those due to severe sinus node dysfunction 
and AV block( Mobitz type II block, complete AV block). Syncope due to bradycardia or asystole is 
referred to as Stokes-Adams attack.

questions.question: Question 21: Interpret the given ECG:
questions.explanation:
The above ECG shows a complete heart block. Features in the ECG supporting the diagnosis of complete heart block: • PP interval is constant • RR interval is constant • P waves more in number than QRS complexes • There is no relation between P waves and the QRS complexes. For a second-degree heart block, the QRS complex should be preceded by the P wave, whereas in 
a third-degree heart block, the QRS complex is independent of the P wave. The ECG features are marked in the image below: 884 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 22: šou observe that an ECG recording revealed a QRS complex > 0.12 seconds. Which of the 
following would you not include in the differential diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
QRS > 0.12s points towards a wide QRS complex. The left anterior fascicular block does not 
cause a wide QRS complex. Fascicular blocks do not prolong the QRS interval. They only lead to axis deviation. • Left anterior fascicular block: left axis deviation • Left posterior fascicular block: right axis deviation Wide QRS complexes ( 0.12 seconds) are seen in the following: • Ventricular tachycardias • Ventricular premature contractions • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome • Bundle branch blocks (complete blocks- QRS interval  0.12 seconds, incomplete blocks- QRS 
interval between 0.10–0.12 seconds) • Hyperkalemia

questions.question:
Question 23: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and 
breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of :
questions.explanation:
The symptoms of weakness, paresthesia, and dyspnea along with the given ECG showing 
depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave (flattening or inversion), 
and an increase in the amplitude of U waves (at the end of the T wave) are characteristic of 
hypokalemia. In the given ECG, leads V1-V6 exhibit T wave inversion. U waves are well appreciated in leads 
V2-V5. 885 
Sold by @itachibot Hypokalemia leads to dynamic ECG changes. The image given shows the sequence of changes 
observed: Hypokalemia is defined as plasma K+ concentration of <3.5meq/L. It can also cause premature 
atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, 
atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation. Other options: Option B: Hyperkalemia causes tall peaked T waves with a shortened QT interval. There is a 
progressive lengthening of the PR interval and QRS duration with an increase in potassium levels, 
eventually leading to the disappearance of the P wave; and widening of the QRS complex to a sine 
wave pattern. 886 
Sold by @itachibot Option C: Hypocalcemia causes prolongation of the QT interval. There is a lengthening of the ST 
segment, while the T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered. Option D: Hypercalcemia causes shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment 
duration. 887 
Sold by @itachibot Valvular Heart Diseases
